question_details.title: Will the US enact export controls for some generative AI software before 2026?
question_details.description:
This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2023-05-17 15:19:00 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/17102). This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

As of May 2023, US law does not have export controls on the sale of software services that include powerful generative AI. As such, OpenAI, Anthropic, Google, and Microsoft can sell LLM-assisted document writing, image generation, video generation, etc. to enterprises worldwide (up to more general export controls not focused on AI.)

In Oct 2022, the [US implemented export controls](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_New_Export_Controls_on_Advanced_Computing_and_Semiconductors_to_China), that, roughly speaking, bans export of semiconductors that involve US in their manufacturing chain to China.

As the capabilities of generative AI systems grow, and as enterprise customers learn more how to extract certain types of knowledge (e.g. how to create Deep Fakes or create armies of online bots), one way US policymakers might address risks would be to apply exports control to software that are similar to the export controls for hardware used for training AI.

`{"format":"metac_closes_in_period","info":{"post_id":17102,"question_id":17102}}`
question_details.resolution_criteria: This question resolves as **YES** if, by Dec 31 2025, the US imposes export controls on some generative AI software, and **NO** otherwise.
question_details.fine_print:
The export controls need not be specifically to China - anything under the standard export regime of the US would qualify.

The export controls must be specifically related to AI that can generate content. It is not sufficient if software produced by Microsoft or OpenAI cannot be exported to certain countries for other reasons - such as export bans on all software, or on all commercial products sold to certain countries.

These need to be actual export controls, as per the 2022 controls on semiconductors. Taxes or trade deals are not considered here.

Here are the relevant news articles:

**3 Big Mistakes for Artificial Intelligence (AI) Growth Stock Investors to Avoid in 2026**
On October 10, 2025, the Nasdaq Composite suffered a 3.6% decline, its worst session since April amid heightened U.S.-China trade tensions. The sell-off followed U.S. threats to impose a 100% tariff on Chinese imports in response to China's tightened export controls on rare-earth minerals and magnets—critical materials for semiconductors and AI-related technologies. On October 12, 2025, reports confirmed China would not back down from these escalating trade threats. The article warns AI growth stock investors preparing for 2026 to avoid three key mistakes. First, over-concentration in a single segment of the AI value chain: for example, investing in Nvidia (NASDAQ: NVDA), Broadcom, and Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) may appear diversified, but all rely heavily on the same major customer—OpenAI—which is building 10 gigawatts of data centers. A cut in OpenAI’s spending could negatively impact all three. Second, investing in semiconductor equipment suppliers like Applied Materials, Lam Research, and ASML, which serve the same large customers—Taiwan Semiconductor, Samsung Electronics, and Intel—means a reduction in spending by any one of them could ripple through the entire equipment sector. Third, overexposure to cloud computing giants—Amazon Web Services, Microsoft Azure, Google Cloud (Alphabet), and Oracle—while these companies benefit from AI demand, they also serve broader corporate computing and storage needs; a slowdown in AI investment or a broader economic downturn could reduce demand across their platforms. **China's latest round of rare-earth export controls gives the country dominion over precious resources  --  regulations have far-reaching implications for the semiconductor industry**
China has expanded its export control regime to include five heavy rare-earth elements—erbium, europium, holmium, thulium, and ytterbium—along with their alloys, oxides, compounds, and finished materials, effective from early November 2025. The controls now extend beyond raw materials to cover products and devices containing Chinese-origin rare earths if the value of those materials exceeds 0.1%, requiring dual-use export licenses from China's Ministry of Commerce. The regulations also encompass over 20 types of rare-earth processing equipment, including centrifugal extraction units, acid-resistant roasting kilns, electrolytic furnaces, and crystal-growth furnaces, as well as mining reagents, separation chemicals, and mineral feedstock. This move solidifies China’s dominance over the global rare-earth supply chain, including mining, refining, and application technologies. The rules prohibit exports to military users, entities on Chinese watch lists, and end uses involving weapons of mass destruction or terrorism. Critically, China’s Ministry of Commerce will review license applications for advanced logic chips (14nm and below), 3D NAND memory (256-layer+), and AI technologies with potential military applications, allowing Beijing to restrict materials to global chipmakers like TSMC and Micron. This marks a strategic shift from being a supplier to a global watchdog over rare-earth use. The controls are part of a multi-stage plan that now spans the entire semiconductor and electronics ecosystem—from wafer substrates to photonics and magnetics. While foreign companies may theoretically switch suppliers, doing so is costly and complex due to the need for requalification of processes and reliance on Chinese technology and know-how. The U.S. responded with a 100% tariff on China-made goods and a ban on 'critical software' for China-based entities. China’s control over both the physical materials and the means of production—including equipment, chemicals, and technical expertise—gives it unprecedented geopolitical leverage. Future expansions could include additional rare earths like neodymium or praseodymium, and potentially end-user controls, mirroring U.S. export enforcement models. The regulation, effective December 1, 2025, applies globally and signals China’s intent to govern the use of rare-earth materials worldwide.

**3 Big Mistakes for Artificial Intelligence (AI) Growth Stock Investors to Avoid in 2026**

A cut in OpenAI’s spending could negatively impact all three. Second, investing in semiconductor equipment suppliers like Applied Materials, Lam Research, and ASML, which serve the same large customers—Taiwan Semiconductor, Samsung Electronics, and Intel—means a reduction in spending by any one of them could ripple through the entire equipment sector. Third, overexposure to cloud computing giants—Amazon Web Services, Microsoft Azure, Google Cloud (Alphabet), and Oracle—while these companies benefit from AI demand, they also serve broader corporate computing and storage needs; a slowdown in AI investment or a broader economic downturn could reduce demand across their platforms. **China’s Export Controls Reveal U.S. Supply Chain Vulnerabilities in Critical Materials**
China has implemented new export controls on lithium batteries, graphite anode materials, and rare earth-related technologies, citing national security and non-proliferation obligations. These measures, announced on October 9, 2024, extend beyond raw materials to include critical equipment, processes, and services—marking a strategic upgrade in resource sovereignty. China dominates global production: over 90% of graphite for anodes, nearly 90% of rare earth oxides, and most NdFeB magnets. The controls target core sectors—clean energy, defense, and semiconductors—precisely those prioritized by the U.S. under the Inflation Reduction Act and CHIPS Act. The U.S. military relies on China for over 78% of materials used in its equipment, and rebuilding domestic rare earth refining capacity would take 5–10 years and billions in investment. China’s restrictions threaten U.S. AI infrastructure growth, with one assessment suggesting GDP growth could fall to under 0.1% in early 2025 without AI capital expansion. The U.S. electric vehicle revolution depends on China’s battery supply chain, with China processing two-thirds of global lithium and over 90% of graphite. Without Chinese technology and equipment, U.S. EV production would face higher costs, lower output, and delayed decarbonization. China’s export controls expose the fragility of U.S. industrial foundations, revealing deep dependency on Chinese supply chains in both green and digital transitions.

**China Expands Export Control on Rare Earth Minerals and More**
On October 9, 2025, China's Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) announced Decree No. 61 and Decree No. 62, significantly expanding export controls over the rare earth supply chain. Decree No. 61 targets foreign-made rare earth metals and products, while Decree No. 62 controls rare earth-related technology. The new rules extend China's export control authority to foreign-made products containing Chinese-origin rare earths or manufactured using Chinese technology, marking a major policy shift. MOFCOM cited cases of foreign entities circumventing controls by transferring Chinese-origin items to military and sensitive end-users, and illegally obtaining rare earth technology for use in sensitive sectors. The rules require foreign exporters to obtain a dual-use item export license from MOFCOM before exporting controlled items to countries outside China. Both initial Chinese exporters and subsequent foreign exporters must issue a compliance notification letter in MOFCOM’s unified format, informing customers that the product contains Chinese-origin rare earths and that further exports may require a Chinese license. The regulations bring nearly all rare earth-related technologies under control, including intellectual property licensing, investment, consulting, joint R&D, and employment. A new end-use restriction applies even to non-controlled items if they are used in foreign rare earth mining, smelting, separation, metal refining, magnetic material manufacturing, or recycling activities. Chinese individuals and organizations are prohibited from supporting such foreign activities without a license. Export applications for advanced semiconductor and AI-related end-uses are subject to case-by-case review by MOFCOM. The '50% Rule' denies export applications to importers and end-users on MOFCOM’s Export Control Watchlist or Concern List, including their subsidiaries and affiliates with 50% or more controlling equity. On the same day, MOFCOM issued four additional decrees restricting exports of rare earth manufacturing equipment, five specific rare earth minerals (Holmium, Erbium, Thulium, Europium, Ytterbium), lithium battery materials, artificial graphite anode materials, and superhard materials, and placed 14 companies on China’s Unreliable Entity List. The rules reflect a strategic effort to counter circumvention and safeguard national security.

**The Washington Post: China Now Leads the U.S. in Open-Source AI Development**
According to an analysis by The Washington Post, China is now leading the United States in the development of open-source artificial intelligence (AI) technologies, despite the U.S. having historically dominated the AI race. While American companies like OpenAI (ChatGPT) and Google (Gemini) are widely regarded as leaders in proprietary AI tools, Chinese firms are surpassing them in open AI models. In 2024, the best open AI models were primarily U.S.-based, but by 2025, all top open models were由中国制造. On LMArena, a blind-testing platform for AI outputs, Chinese models from companies like Alibaba and DeepSeek outperformed U.S. models from OpenAI and Meta. Hugging Face, a leading AI model-sharing platform, reported that DeepSeek’s open model received 12.8k upvotes—double the 6.3k for Meta’s top Llama model—while OpenAI ranked fifth with 4.0k. Irene Solaiman, Hugging Face’s Chief Policy Officer, noted that Chinese companies are more prolific in releasing high-quality models. Although OpenAI’s latest open model ranked ahead of DeepSeek in tests by Artificial Analysis, Solaiman emphasized that Chinese firms are also leading in open-source tools for image and video generation. The article highlights concerns in the U.S. over losing ground in open AI, prompting initiatives like the ATOM project (American Truly Open Models) to develop competitive open models. Meta’s Mark Zuckerberg, while advocating for open AI in 2023, later cautioned about 'carefully selecting' what to open-source, signaling a shift toward retaining proprietary advantages. The debate centers on whether open AI fosters innovation and global leadership or risks ceding strategic control to competitors.

**Global Tech: Trade Tensions Resurge — How Investors Should Respond**
In an unexpected escalation, the United States threatened to impose tariffs of up to 100% on Chinese imports in response to China's new export controls on rare earth elements and other critical raw materials. The self-reinforcing capital ecosystem, prevalent among U.S. mega-cap tech firms, is seen as a model that governments may actively encourage to speed up critical infrastructure development. Leading semiconductor supply chain companies have been proactively diversifying their operations and revenue structures, driven significantly by increasingly strict U.S. export controls. DBS tracking of six major semiconductor and IC design firms shows that revenue from China fell from nearly 40% in 2018 to about 22% in 2024. This strategic shift—whether voluntary or externally driven—has reduced dependence on a single market. If Trump administration policies lead to stricter export controls or a complete ban on Chinese exports, these now more diversified companies are expected to experience manageable impacts on growth and fundamentals.

**SB 243: California Enacts New AI Law to Protect Youth from Harmful Chatbot Interactions**
California has passed SB 243, a new law regulating AI chatbots to protect youth and vulnerable adults. The law mandates that AI chatbots must be clearly identifiable as such and prohibits them from impersonating medical professionals, therapists, or other experts—practices previously reported to have occurred. The law specifically targets minors, who are more susceptible to harmful advice due to lack of experience, though protections extend to vulnerable adults as well. Key provisions include mandatory age verification systems, with OpenAI planning to implement one for ChatGPT starting December 2025, which will also unlock adult-only features like erotic conversations. Chatbots must log conversations that veer into dangerous territory, provide resources for help, prompt users to take breaks, block inappropriate content for minors, and warn users about risks before use. The law also strengthens penalties for AI-generated deepfake pornography and holds AI providers liable for damages. The law applies broadly to major providers like Meta, OpenAI, xAI, Google, and specialized platforms such as Character.ai and Replika, which allow users to create personalized AI companions—criticized for potential harm to children. The law was prompted by incidents including a 16-year-old’s suicide allegedly supported by ChatGPT and a 13-year-old girl’s case involving Character.ai, along with leaked documents showing Meta’s chatbots engaging in romantic conversations with minors. SB 243 follows California’s earlier AI law, SB 53, which focused on transparency. While other U.S. states are considering similar legislation, former President Donald Trump previously opposed AI regulation, citing concerns about U.S. competitiveness with China in the AI race. The law takes effect in January 2026.

**China Dodges US Export Controls, Buys $38 Billion In Chipmaking Equipment, Congress Report Says**
A bipartisan report by the U.S. House of Representatives Select Committee on China reveals that China purchased approximately $38 billion in sophisticated semiconductor manufacturing equipment from the U.S. and its allies in 2024, marking a 66% increase from 2022 when export restrictions were introduced. The report attributes this surge to inconsistencies in export control rules among the U.S., Japan, and the Netherlands, which allowed non-U.S. equipment makers to sell to certain Chinese firms that U.S. companies were barred from supplying. Chinese firms acquired equipment from five major suppliers—Applied Materials (NASDAQ:AMAT), ASML (AMS:ASML), Lam Research (NASDAQ:LRCX), KLA (NASDAQ:KLA), and Tokyo Electron (TYO:8035)—without violating laws. China accounted for nearly 39% of the combined sales of these firms in 2024, with most revenue coming from state-owned enterprises. Between 2022 and 2024, each supplier more than doubled its share of global revenue from Chinese state-owned companies. U.S. lawmakers urged allies to implement broader bans on chipmaking equipment exports to China, strengthen enforcement, prevent equipment diversion, and increase support for domestic and allied semiconductor industries through oversight, funding, and talent development. The report emphasizes that China’s semiconductor industry must face 'meaningful restrictions across the entire chain of semiconductor production' amid ongoing U.S. efforts to limit China’s access to advanced chips critical for artificial intelligence and military technologies. The U.S. and China are also competing to export advanced technologies, including AI data centers, globally.

**U.S. Lawmakers Warn of China’s $38 Billion Semiconductor Equipment Purchases, Call for Full Export Ban**
The U.S. House Select Committee on the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) released a 52-page report titled 'Selling the Forges of the Future' on October 8, 2025, revealing that Chinese entities legally purchased approximately $38 billion worth of semiconductor manufacturing equipment (SME) in 2024—up 66% from 2022. This accounted for 39% of the combined sales of the five leading SME suppliers: ASML (Netherlands), Tokyo Electron (TEL, Japan), KLA (U.S.), Applied Materials (U.S.), and Lam Research (Lam Research, U.S.). Sales to Chinese state-owned enterprises (SOEs) surged from $9.5 billion in 2022 to $26.2 billion in 2024. The report identifies five entities linked to China’s military and intelligence apparatus among major buyers, including Pengxinxu, SwaySure, and Qingdao Sien Technology—companies previously named by the U.S. Congress for aiding Huawei in circumventing sanctions. Committee Chair John Moolenaar stated that Western equipment manufacturers are sacrificing U.S. national security for profit, warning that continued exports risk undermining America’s technological and military edge. Democratic lead Raja Krishnamoorthi emphasized the absurdity of selling tools to produce chips used in military modernization and human rights abuses. The report identifies four national security threats from China’s SME procurement: military applications in 'intelligent warfare' relying on AI and advanced computing; efforts to build a vertically integrated semiconductor industry to withstand future export controls; economic dominance in both traditional and advanced chip production; and the use of AI for domestic repression and exporting 'digital authoritarianism.' The committee urges U.S. allies to align export controls with American restrictions, implement broad 'country-wide controls' to prevent circumvention, establish a whistleblower program, increase resources for the Department of Commerce’s Bureau of Industry and Security (BIS) and the State Department, and impose a full ban on SME component exports to China. The report warns equipment makers to view China and its national champions as long-term threats, not valuable customers.

**Export Controls Have Gaps: U.S. Report Finds Chinese Firms Still Purchasing Semiconductor Equipment at Scale**
A report by the U.S. House Select Committee on China, released on October 7, 2025, reveals that Chinese companies purchased approximately $38 billion in semiconductor manufacturing equipment from five major global suppliers—Applied Materials, KLA, Lam Research Corporation (U.S.), ASML (Netherlands), and Tokyo Electron Ltd (Japan)—in 2024, a 66% increase from 2022. These purchases accounted for 39% of the combined global revenue of these firms, with most transactions involving Chinese state-owned enterprises linked to the People's Liberation Army, intelligence agencies, and Huawei-affiliated companies. Although the equipment sold was not always the most advanced, many still contributed to China’s development of advanced chip manufacturing capabilities. The report highlights that current export controls are ineffective due to loopholes: while the most advanced equipment is banned, less advanced but still useful equipment can still be exported with permits. Additionally, after companies are added to the U.S. Entity List, new affiliated entities often emerge that are not yet sanctioned and can continue purchasing U.S. equipment. The report also notes a disparity between U.S. and non-U.S. firms: American companies face stricter restrictions than their foreign counterparts, who can still sell to listed Chinese firms. The committee’s chairman, Republican John Moolenaar, warned that allowing China access to critical semiconductor equipment would lead to U.S. defeat in the technological arms race. Democrat Raja Krishnamoorthi stated that selling equipment to China enables military modernization and human rights abuses, and emphasized the need for allied cooperation to maintain U.S. leadership in semiconductor manufacturing technology. The committee recommends expanding export bans beyond individual companies, aligning allied controls with U.S. standards, and establishing a new whistleblower export control program. According to Craig Singleton of the Foundation for Defense of Democracies, China is attempting to reshape global supply chains, turning niche equipment markets into new battlegrounds. Tokyo Electron’s U.S. CEO Mark Dougherty acknowledged a decline in sales to China due to new regulations, but stressed the need for stronger U.S.-Japan coordination, noting that 'the result the U.S. wants has not yet been achieved.' Applied Materials and Lam Research did not respond to requests for comment; ASML and KLA said they needed to review the report before commenting.

**The risks of export controls on AI chips**
US export controls on advanced AI chips, particularly those from Nvidia and AMD, have fundamentally reshaped semiconductor design and global supply chains. Since 2018, the US Department of Commerce’s Bureau of Industry and Security (BIS) has imposed strict limits on performance, memory bandwidth, and interconnect speeds to restrict China’s access to cutting-edge AI hardware. These regulations led to the creation of downgraded, export-compliant variants such as the Nvidia A800 (400 GBps interconnect bandwidth vs. 600 GBps on the A100), H800 (300 GBps vs. 900 GBps on the H100), and later the H20, which met updated 2023 performance and density caps. These chips were intentionally crippled via firmware, clock adjustments, and reduced memory speeds—turning engineering into compliance. The policy has driven Chinese companies like Huawei to surge in demand for their Ascend 910 series, while European stakeholders, alarmed by US restrictions—including proposed 2025 rules that would have extended export limits to EU allies—began planning to de-Americanize their supply chains. Although the US withdrew the controversial 'AI Diffusion Rule' in mid-2025 and resumed limited sales of H20 and AMD MI308 to China under special licenses, the long-term consequences include fractured global trust, accelerated development of rival ecosystems, and a shift in R&D investment from US firms to Chinese competitors. The result is a paradox: policies meant to maintain technological dominance may instead be fueling innovation in rival nations, undermining long-term US leverage. As one analysis notes, 'When policy, rather than physics, dictates chip specifications, innovation suffers.'

**Moolenaar pushes AI chip export limits to secure U.S. edge over China**
U.S. Rep. John Moolenaar (R‑MI) wrote a letter to Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick on Aug. 25 urging the adoption of a rolling technical threshold (RTT) approach to AI‑chip exports to China. The approach would allow U.S. firms to sell chips that are only marginally better than the most advanced chips China can produce domestically, thereby extending Chinese dependence on U.S. hardware while limiting China’s frontier AI development. Moolenaar said the policy should cap China’s aggregate AI compute at 10 percent of the U.S. level, a move he argues is essential for enduring U.S. AI dominance. He warned that China’s technology proliferation could also empower Russia, Iran, and proxy groups, noting that Iran ‘will be eager to take advantage of PRC‑enabled AI capabilities.’ The letter emphasizes that export controls must balance protecting U.S. semiconductor companies, maintaining U.S. hardware dominance, and limiting China’s AI capabilities. Moolenaar added that selling chips directly to Chinese firms can keep them reliant on U.S. hardware, but allowing them to acquire even moderately better chips would undermine U.S. hyperscalers such as Google, Microsoft, Amazon, and frontier labs like OpenAI, Anthropic, Google, xAI, and Meta. The proposed RTT approach, he said, would give U.S. AI hardware companies a clear advantage in the Chinese market through both direct sales and cloud access, providing clarity for the commercial sector and national‑security community about U.S. export‑control objectives.

summary: Expert forecasts on whether the US will enact export controls for some generative AI software before 2026 show a broad consensus that the probability is elevated compared to historic base rates, due to acute US-China technology tensions and recent news of imminent 'critical software' bans, but uncertainty remains high. Those specializing in US export law and policy processes (e.g., Export Administration Regulations, Wassenaar Arrangement) give lower probabilities (13–35%), citing the lack of public rulemaking, technical and legal challenges of regulating software, bureaucratic inertia, and the historically slow pace of software export controls. National security, political science, and China studies experts place more weight on the exceptional context of 2025, bipartisan Congressional and executive branch pressure, the rapid escalation of tit-for-tat controls, and recent US policy announcements, pushing probabilities into the 65–90% range. Economic statecraft, international relations, technonationalist, and punctuated equilibrium theorists similarly foresee a high likelihood (70–80%) due to the unprecedented policy window, but they note strong industry resistance, enforcement difficulties, and potential for watered-down or narrowly scoped rules. Across all perspectives, doubts linger about the exact definitions and scope of new 'critical software' controls, implementation speed within the 2.5-month window, and whether generative AI software will be explicitly named or only partially covered. Thus, while most experts believe the probability of a YES outcome is above base rates and reflects the intense current pressures, estimates cluster in two groups: legal/regulatory experts (13–35%) remain skeptical due to process constraints, while geopolitical/national security/policy change experts (65–90%) see rapid escalation and strong signals as making new controls on generative AI software likely but not certain by year-end.
